text:
Let's try to get started. So I'm Pedro. I'm an associate professor
in computer science at the University of Chicago.

I run the lab called Human
Computer Integration Lab. And that's really what I'm
going to talk about today-- is this notion or idea of what
happens after wearable devices

and how might computers start
to integrate more intimately with our physical body. Before it gets too
abstract and we

start debating
what I mean exactly with the metaphor
of integration, I just wanted to show
you one quick example.

This is an older work of
mine called muscle-plotter. And what you see here are two
car designers doing what they do best, sketching
and figuring out

which is-- these two car
shapes, the car body, is most aerodynamic. They're trying to
figure out which one would flow best against
the wind and provide less drag.

Normally, they would stop here
and go to a wind simulator, Autodesk 5000 wind simulator.

But these folks are
going to continue to work on the pen and
paper type of model, but actually do access
a wind simulator.

Notice that the person
wrote "wind tunnel 10 meters per second" on the top. And all of a sudden,
they're actually

getting these lines,
which is the computed wind flow as the wind would
actually traverse

the cross-section of this car. And you can see there's some
turbulent wind in the back. Now, the question is, how are
they doing this simulation,

because I don't see a computer? I don't see anything else. And so the simulation is there. There is a computer. It's in the background
of this image.

You don't see it. But the special part here is
that the user doesn't know the output of a simulation.

That's why we need these
computer simulations since complex fluid dynamics
is non-intuitive and all that.

What's actually happening
is that those electrodes on the right side are
connected to the user's arms.

And there's a little computer
that has simulated the sketches. And they're sending
tiny electrical impulses that cause the user's arm to
move left or right involuntarily

you cede your arm's
control to the computer. It takes over. And there's a little bit
of a turn-taking thing.

And it outputs the
wind flow simulation. And the person
actually continues to work on this for
about 10 minutes.

And they really
drill down and find that it's the tail winds
that are the problem. I invite you to watch
this or any of the videos

on YouTube if you're
interested in the rest of that. So I hope you're asking
the same question that I was when I started
having these ideas, which

is, why should we do this? What's the point of
a computer scientist sticking electrodes
onto people's muscles

and trying to control
them-- for what purpose? And I think one of
the things that I think is really interesting is
to look at how far has computing

become in the last
100 years or so, which is really a
much broader lens

than most folks tend to take. And so this precedes me. But some of you in this room
might still remember these times

where universities like
Stanford had one computer. And that one computer
sat in one room. And people fought to have
time on that computer.

And they would spend
maybe an hour a day with that computer,
running their code and their simulations. So computers were
bigger than the users.

It's the-- what I'm
trying to represent here with these bubbles. And then there was a
fantastic revolution

powered by many, many,
many pioneers in HCI. Of course, Douglas
Engelbart is one of the most famous in
this territory in which

the computer starts to
change and shift size and equals the user. And now it's sitting eight
hours in your office.

And you can talk to a
computer interactively very fast for eight hours a day. And we all know where this goes.

This goes into the
user's pockets. This is the most famous
device of all times because apparently, we have
more mobile phones than we ever

had any other kind of computer. Everybody has one of these,
including me, in their pockets.

And so now you're actually
accessing a computer anytime, anywhere, as you walk around. What I'm trying
to depict here is

that notice every
shift in interface affords us to do
completely new things.

It's really big. And we know it
doesn't stop here. If I shift this to today,
we're with wearable devices.

Sometimes in my
Intro to HCI class, I joke with my students,
the first-years, and say, well, you take this,
two Velcro straps, put it here.

That doesn't seem like
a great invention. You call it a smartwatch
or a wearable. But it truly is
a great invention

because what you are now able
to do with something touching your skin 24/7 is very different
from just in your pocket.

such as your skin, senses heart
rate, and so forth, so forth. It's at the skin level. It's very different from
at the pocket level.

Pocket level is great, too,
but affords different things. And so what I spend my waking
time, and sometimes dream time,

too, is on this question-- I hope you all spend
some time there, too-- which is, what comes after that?

And now if you believe
this bubble analogy where the device becomes
smaller first and then

starts to approximate the
user's body to the point that the wearable is like that
first initial contact just

with the skin, then you might
ask all kinds of questions. For example, what
would happen if we

designed for that
overlap over there where the two circles integrate? And that's what I'm going
to talk about today.

And I think the first example
that I picked for you today with the muscle-plotter is an extreme
example of that integration

because the system
intentionally borrows parts of the user's body-- in
this case, the muscles--

to really perform its function. If you would ask a
exam-type question, please indicate all the hardware
components of muscle-plotter,

at some point, you have
to say "the muscles" because without the muscles,
there would be no plotting.

There would be no output. And so that's the
type of connection that I'm going to
explore here today

with this idea of devices
that integrate with the body. So I'm going to just lead
you a little bit historically

with my work because it
tells a larger story of why I'm interested in these things. And so the first
track of research

I started doing along these
lines of bodily integration with wearable devices is
about the question of,

can we move into a future
where virtual realities are more realistic? Notice that a lot of
people in these images

are wearing some kind of virtual
reality headset in the sense that we are now immersed in a
world that you go to Target,

you buy a VR headset for $300. And what do you see in it? Visually, it's very,
very impressive.

I never actually thought
I would see that. And that came within
10 years of me saying I don't think we'll
ever see photorealism.

And now we're there. This actually-- we're
showing two scenes. Here, this is maybe where y'all
are going today later, Tahoe,

and a desert scene. And these are not
even Pixar-level VR. This is just made
by my student Jas overnight as they were trying
to set up an experiment in VR.

So imagine what
real VR looks like. Now, while the visual
realism is immense,

this illusion breaks
down really easily if I start to try to
interact with this and expect physicality.

If I go to that
Lake Tahoe mountain and try to push through
that wall over there, I know that there's no way
that $300 headset that I bought

at Target has any
hardware whatsoever to provide that
physical force feedback,

that realism of touching
a resistive force, and just my hands standing
there at the wall of that shed.

And so that's one
of the things that I think today is stopping VR
from becoming a really, really

immersive training simulation
for learning physical skills. It's fantastic for gaming.

But if you actually want to
learn physical skills that transfer to the real world, we
need that type of sensation.

And so maybe some of
you know that we've solved this problem before. I shouldn't be talking
about this problem before. Sean certainly knows
that we've solved it

before in the field of
robotics with things like this. This is an exoskeleton device. I really like this one. It's called UL7 by Perry et al.

And what you see here
is a person in VR. They're just not
wearing the goggles. But notice that they're
playing with this ball.

The ball goes up and
down the incline. And they feel the
resistive force as all these motors push
against their joints.

And they-- like, wow it's hard
to push the ball up the incline because the force of gravity.

It's a beautiful device. It's really easy to control. And it's very
precise and all that. But unfortunately,
this type of device

is completely at
odds with the VR that we're experiencing today. This is where VR is at.

And I'm even showing VR headsets
that you can't buy anymore. That's old Quests.

So you can buy the new ones. You can buy the Apple ones. You can buy whatever it is. But it's all untethered, mobile,
free-form tracking everything.

Even the tracking
is done inside out. There's absolutely not
even more base stations installations,
whereas this thing

requires to be
bolted to the wall to provide a resistive force. You know Newton's third law. And it's always a hard one.

And also, lots of batteries
because motors, power, so forth, so forth, so forth. So one of the first
things that we thought

when we started working on
this idea of integration with the body is perhaps
this allows us to make

this device much smaller. Perhaps if we go
directly to the body, we don't need huge batteries
and motors and so forth.

And so we wanted to do a still
very realistic force feedback device, but without
the constraints

and trying to circumvent
physics in a creative way by trying to really get the
same output force, even. And so what I'm going
to show you here

is how we got inspired by
medicine and neuroscience and took this technique
that exists since the '60s,

really, called electrical
muscle stimulation, when you apply a tiny
little electrical impulse over a pair of electrodes.

In this case, if you would
apply it over these two, your hand actually
moves upwards like that.

This is an involuntary reaction
that works just because muscles are tiny electrical machines. And they always do
that in the presence

of an electrical current. Now, you can put these
things together and think, doctors are fiddling
with the knobs

when they do these therapies
using electrical muscle stimulation. But what if the electrical
muscle stimulation

is the interface for you to feel
these forces in virtual reality? Putting that together, and
this is work I did in my PhD

with Patrick Baudisch
at HPI, you're going to get
experiences like this.

So this is a person in VR. And when they touch these walls,
their hands cannot penetrate

through the wall because their
muscles recoil just in time to provide this illusion of
force that comes from their own

body. This last room here-- I'm actually fast-forwarding
and cutting a scene here.

But the last room was
really a fun thing to do at CHI and at SIGGRAPH
because we're really trying to emulate the thing
you saw with exoskeleton.

This person is literally
trying to pick up this cube. The cube should have weight
if we're doing it properly. And so what I do here is
make their muscles go down.

They have to fight the
involuntary going down. And that interaction of forces
feels like force feedback.

There's something
pulling me down. And I'm pulling up--
feels like force feedback. So it creates this
sense of realism,

this heightened realism in VR. And again, the
obvious advantages here is that the hardware
is so much smaller.

The weird thing about the
talk that I'm giving today is that I'm a hardware person. But my goal is to take
out hardware things.

Instead of adding more hardware
to create these sensations-- for example, pushing
the hand with a motor

to generate a wall-- I'm actually searching for parts
in the body that can already do that and ask myself
the question, what

is the minimum set of
electronic components that I need to talk to
that part of the body? And in this case, the
muscle stimulation

talks to the muscles. The muscles do the force. Well, that's so much smaller
than going the motor route. I'm not going to show
you a lot of hardware.

But I wanted to at
least show you just one so you see there's
really nothing special about these types of devices. And so I just chose
this old device

that I made back
in '16 for Wist. And it's just one of electrical
muscle stimulation bracelets.

There's all the normal
things you would expect. Here there's a little
Arduino microcontroller that talks to the VR application
over wireless or Bluetooth,

in this case. And really, the
key part is this. This is the same thing
doctors are using,

the medical-grade muscle
stimulator, except in this case, we're just controlling digitally
rather than with the knobs.

And then there's batteries. Now, the fun part is this stuff
here you all know very well.

This is all solid-state
electronics. This is all normal components. Moore's law operates here.

So this is in 2016. I'm not an electrical engineer. I'm computer science-- I know-- I have no idea how
to make hardware.

I made this thing really big. But I had this feeling of
like, this part can go small. The electrodes, though, you
need to have a certain size,

and I'm happy to talk
about limitations later, to address that muscle. The beautiful thing is
that that's-- part is soft.

It's made of fabric. It's kind of like a
tissue type thing. So you can put it
in your clothes. There's lots of people
trying to do that

for rehabilitation purposes
and interactive purposes, too. But what I'm trying
to say is this is miniaturizable really easily.

And in fact, my
student, Jas Brooks, did one that is so small
that it goes inside the nose. I'm happy to show you later why
we put electrical stimulator

inside of the nose. But it's literally the same
circuit, the same device. It has battery and Bluetooth.

It's literally the same one. But it can be
really, really small if you're a better
engineer than me, which is the case of Jas and
many other of my students.

Now, what I think is
interesting-- just as I told you that every time we had a
revolution in HCI paradigm,

we were able to do
new applications that the previous paradigm
made no sense for, I think

there are new
applications here that come from this new paradigm. So I'm not going to
show a lot of them.

But a lot of them are about
haptic force feedback-- so feeling forces in VR. But I want to show this
one from my student, Yudai,

because I think he took it to
a slightly different territory that is very, very interesting. Yudai and I had
talked a lot about how

people train to do things. I don't know if you have to
do fire training safety here. I'm sure you do. We do that every
year in Chicago.

And it's those things that you
watch a video for 10 minutes and then you click,
yes, I know how to act in the case of a
fire, which is not exactly

the same as knowing how to
act in the case of a fire because you don't have this
embodied immediate sense of what

I should actually do
when the stakes are high. And so what you're seeing
here is an application that Yudai made where
people are training the fire

safety in my actual lab. So they're learning what should
you do if that happens, a fire.

The fire is virtual in this
case, augmented reality. And the person actually misses
where the fire extinguisher

is at. So Yudai's system detects that. They've dwelled
too long on that. It uses the muscle
stimulation on their neck

to guide their point of
view to the actual location so they can continue
the training and get that muscle memory
of like, it's over there,

it's under the desk. That feeling of it's
to the left and down is what we're depicting here.

The rest of the
video is really cool. I invite you to see it actually
teaches you fire safety. If the fire breaks in the
ceiling, always evacuate.

There's no point in taking out
a fire that is in the ceiling. And that system
also tells you where the fire exit is at by
showing you with your head

where you should go. It's really, really fun. Again, people in robotics
have been doing this forever.

We got inspired by them. Really, the idea of head
actuation is there before. But the type of hardware is very
prohibitive for an application

like training. This is really a medical
rehabilitation exoskeleton. Now, you can only use-- in particular conditions.

But having almost no
hardware over here, just these soft
electrodes-- it's a totally different
type of scenario.

So I wanted to emphasize
that and close the chapter on these force feedback
and talk a little bit

about more of the rest of the
work that we've been doing. So I put you now
historically at the point where I started my lab at the
University of Chicago about four

or five years ago
in which I really didn't know if what we had
done with muscles was possible,

this integration with
the user's muscles was possible, in
other modalities. That was the question that I was
really excited to figure out.

And so we started to move
to different sensory systems of the person's body and
ask the question again,

can I make a device
with less hardware by talking to the biology
that the body already has?

which I think is really fun. These two experiences
here-- being in a desert, being in a snowy
mountain-- are not

going to feel real if there's
no temperature component. When you think of desert,
you think really, really hot.

And so people in HCI, of
course, have figured this out. This is, again, really
important for training.

What they use is any
kind of mechanical device that can do that. For example, this
is a heat lamp--

of course, one
kilowatt of power-- so a really heavy device. Again, I'm not clear how the
VR headset we have today--

we already have problems
with the battery-- of the new headsets are going
to last for generating a cooling

or heating sensation. So the question,
again-- same story. How do we make this
more power-efficient

by going to the body? Jas's solution that we published
a while back at CHI, CHI 2020,

is to actually find another
illusion in the human body. So what you see here
is a person in VR.

And they are wearing a
device on their nose. Temperature of the room--

completely controlled
at 20 degrees Celsius. So nothing is changing. Yet they're warming their
hands in this furnace.

And they think
something is changing. What's actually
happening is we're pulverizing a tiny, tiny
bit of smell in their nose.

And now you're
wondering, well, smell doesn't feel like temperature. It has nothing to do with--
these two sensory systems have nothing to do with one another.

But let me just zoom in
the nose for a second and talk about these
weird receptors that we have in our nose and,
by the way, all over our skin.

If you heat them up, we must be
feeling temperature, somehow. So there's a little temperature
sensor in our skin receptors

that fires, of course, to
indicate whatever temperature we're feeling. But then what about chemicals?

So what about when you go
to the Indian restaurant and have spicy food? Don't you feel hot? So what's happening there?

It turns out these receptors
at a cellular level have also a chemical
mechanism that fires.

The only reason why when
you're having spicy food and you know it's the spicy
food and not temperature is because the contextual
cues are very obvious.

You're like, we're eating. That particular cell
has no idea if we're eating or not-- happy to
talk about the thoughts

that biologists have of why that
receptor is there for chemical. But it's probably a
signaling mechanism.

And so we're doing that. As crazy as it might sound,
what this device is actually projecting is a
minuscule amount--

I want to emphasize that-- 0.1 microliters of capsaicin
in a droplet form factor.

The person inhales that. And that's enough to make
them feel like it's hot. And then we flip to
another component

here, which is eucalyptol--
if you ever had a breath mint, you feel very refreshed
with the breath mint.

Eucalyptol or menthol
do the same thing, but on the opposite
side of the channel. So what they do is create a
cooling sensation as the other--

is another receptor
that you have inside of your trigeminal
nerve that does that. And the person is walking
outside in the snow.

It feels like this
arctic blast of Chicago as they walk outside, certainly
not the Stanford emulation here.

What's really
interesting, and this is-- it's all kind
of limitations here. But it is an illusion.

So it's much weaker
than real temperature. But the power consumption
is ridiculous. We just need to activate this
little ultrasonic emitter

and get a droplet
floating in the air. James? Do you feel it more in your
head than the rest of your body?

This is such a good question. So that's what we thought. And I would say
many of participants

just felt this localized thing. It should actually
feel localized because as you
pointed out, it goes through this trigeminal
nerve, innervates

the face-- end of the story. That being said,
some people reported to feel it on the whole body.

I remember Jas once
running to my office and saying, great result-- participant took out
their scarf and they're doing this and whatnot.

n equals that one participant
doesn't mean a lot. But it should be
localized, which is one of the downsides
of this-- so not true room

temperature type things. I think in conjunction
with the visuals in VR starts to make this
feeling of spreading.

But it's an illusory feeling. So awesome question. And again, what I'm emphasizing
here is the same trick.

My trick is just to not put the
heater there-- is just to say, is there a heater in the
body that I can leverage?

And it turns out there is one. It's really low-power. So very exciting. In fact, Jasmine and
Jas took this further

in a paper called
"Chemical Haptics," where because we have all our skin
cells-- have these receptors,

you can do all kinds
of things, again, in virtual-- for the sake of
virtual reality here on the skin

cells. So you can do cooling
here in the cheeks. This is actually a
fantastic experience. If you ever go to
my lab, please ask

Jasmine for that cooling one. It feels arctic-cold
when your cheeks are receiving menthol over here.

Did you try other
locations, like the ears, since people are wearing
stuff and most of us don't? We just had a
discussion the other day

about ears because also, you
use that to thermoregulate. So it could actually
help people that have problems thermoregulating.
We have not tried it. So I would love to, actually. It's really, really fantastic. We can do other things.

This is actually a training
application as well. So another type of
training we have to do because we
work with chemicals

is what do you do if you
spill a chemical on your desk or something. And by the way, it's
wash your hands, wash your eyes in that order.

Never flip that order. But there's no sense of
training and heightened impact when you're watching
a video on YouTube

about this and just click Yes. Here, it actually simulates. So there's a chemical
passing through your skin.

And these open channels
of silicone-- the channels are open. Your skin absorbs the
chemical very slowly.

It feels like stinging,
like tickling. It's a safe type of stinging. It's really interesting. We can create this
heightened realism

like you're actually in
that chemical spill moment. But it's all a safe simulation. We can do lots of weird things.

We can actually use lidocaine,
the same thing your dentist uses-- this is a topical
lidocaine, so it's very, very weak numbing--

and remove sensations. I have no idea what
to do with that. So if you have ideas, I'm
always searching for that.

I call it negative haptics. But I've never said
that out loud too much. Again, same idea-- all
my colleagues in haptics,

and many of you
know this well, have been trying to make better and
better actuators to address

all these senses individually. What's interesting here is that
the skin has these sensors. Many of them are
chemically triggered.

So you can find a new pathway
to generate sensations with one single device. Now, at this point, I want
to emphasize that we're--

I'm tricking you a
little bit because I talked about integration
with computers. I talked about
desktops, wearables.

All those systems
have input and output. And then I'm just showing
you a haptics talk, where I only talk about output.

And it feels a
little misleading. So I think the next step in my
research was to close this loop

and imagine the same question,
integrated devices with a body, but now this time, they
can do input and output.

What would it mean
to compute a variable or feel a variable through my
body alone, not sense of vision

and so forth? And so I could show you
all kinds of older work. But I actually want to
sidestep a little bit

to the more recent
things where we're really looking at how can
we assist folks with acquisition of skills.

So you want to learn
how to play piano? The only way people address
that with computers now

is watching a YouTube video
and trying to follow along. And that's fair. I get a lot of YouTube videos
learning how to play piano.

But I can't understand
how much force I should put in a movement. I can't even train my muscles
to actually do that instead of--

I'm just stuck in this
loop of translating what I see to how I should move. And so this is work by
my now postdoc Aki--

this was actually when
he was an intern-- where we found a way to
do the muscle stimulation approach on the back
of the hand to get

these more precise movements. So this is not Aki
playing, but just the computer playing for him.

This is the James Bond song,
if you haven't realized it. And of course, we're
now in the process

of trying to find out how much
this is actually teach you in-- compared to a piano teacher
and compared to just watching

a score and compared to
games where you play piano and VR and all kinds of things. But it sounds like from very
early results, the question

of, for example, force,
how much pressure should I put, this does
it really, really well.

The question of how fast-- it
seems very dependent on people whether, they want the physical
mode of training or not.

But the results aren't out yet. Now, I want to
emphasize, and this applies to all the
muscle stimulation stuff,

this is really, really difficult
to do with a lot of precision. I'm sure if you play piano,
you were like, Pedro,

that is not a very elegant
piano playing technique. Fingers are going
slightly sideways.

It actually only
moves one joint. It flexes all the way. It doesn't really
stop at the point. You're like, this is not good.

Yes-- absolutely with you. And in fact, if you
drill into the results of the muscle-plotter one,
the first one I showed you

with the cars and
the wind tunnel, the system is fairly precise. Sometimes, I used
to give this talk and say, oh, it has 4
millimeters of error.

And people were really
excited about 4 millimeters. And now I just say,
think of, for example, Michael is taking notes.

Each letter is smaller
than 4 millimeters. So this thing can't even
do one single letter,

much less a letter properly. But especially-- although it can
follow the trajectory very well,

notice how much it jitters. It cannot stop very well. It can go really well
and can reach a target.

But it has no idea how to stop
at that target and stay there. It's a very difficult
control problem. And a lot of, actually,
biomechanical people

look at this problem. And some of them like
muscle-plotter and tell me this is useful. But I also recognize
nobody really knows

how to solve this problem. We've been trying to
solve the control problem, how to stop the
muscle stimulation,

by now taking a full
loop and being inspired by the exoskeleton approach. This is actually work that
Yujie helped do in my lab

when she just joined and
was spearheaded by Romain with the help of Shan-Yuan. And so here, we're trying to
take the muscle stimulation

to the next level. Not only we're able to
do individual fingers, but stop at very precise
angles, the kind of thing

you would need if you wanted
to automatically learn how to do a guitar chord. So in this case, the
left hand of Romain

is controlled by the
muscle stimulation plus a small mechanical device
that assists with stopping

in the right place. So he didn't create that chord. He's just strumming along. And that chord was created
by the muscle stimulation.

And the reason why
this is more precise, and you can see it
here better in the demo where Yujie is actually
speaking in sign language,

is we're using
muscle stimulation. But we're also using an
additional mechanical device

here, these
mechanical brakes that are very small and
worn on the fingers. So in this demo, actually,
Yujie and Romain are talking.

Romain has no idea about
American Sign Language. And he's using a little
translator application to film Yujie and
understand what she asked.

She asked, what's your major? He's going to respond
just textually, HCI, human-computer interaction.

And what's happening
is that that data gets sent to the glove. And the glove now decides
which fingers are free to move

and which fingers should
be locked in place. And so now it doesn't matter how
precise your muscle stimulation is because if there is a
movement that would accidentally

be created, it's locked. And it can't happen. So we selectively choose
which fingers are free,

we would ever be able to do. So here you can see
the mechanical brakes. This one is locking
and locking just

so you can see the ratchet palm
mechanism just for a second. And now you can
actually see an H in sign language, a pretty
good C, I would say.

And the I is all over
the place a little bit. But this is a completely
different level of realism

for precision for finger
poses that we've never able to do before. So again, the
question here that I'm

really interested in
right now is, does it help to learn these things
to feel the muscle memory? And by the way, I must say this
is an incredibly small subset.

If you speak American
Sign Language, there is the whole face. There's the whole body. There's the distance
between these two things.

We can't do any of that. But we're fingerspelling some
very simple selected characters. I must say the H, C,
and I is what we can do.

[CHUCKLING] So I want to emphasize that. Now, notice what I think happens
in this track of research

where we start here with
very simple movements. And we start going
here and saying, wow, you maybe are struggling
to learn guitar.

And we can help. And you're struggling
to learn sign language. We can help. And you're not great at
drawing these things.

And we can maybe
help a little bit. And you have to ask
the question of, where do we stop extending
the ability and actually

endow people with a new ability
that their bodies might not be able to do? And so that's what I've
been doing, actually,

since a few years back. And here's an extreme
example of that that my postdoc and I worked
on-- four or five years on,

which is accelerating
someone's reaction time. I don't know if your doctors
ever performed this test on you.

This is a cognitive aging
test called a pen drop test. They drop a pen and see if
you can catch it quickly.

This is actually very hard. So they calibrate it by
putting the pen more up so you can actually do it.

Now, it's super naive. After you saw my talk, you
know what I'm going to do. I'm going to put the electrodes. There's a camera--
tracks the pen.

Done, accelerated reaction time,
as fast as humanly possible. In fact, it's so
ridiculously fast

that Jun and I got a
Guinness Book Award for that, which is very strange thing.

And I can talk
about that process. They come to the lab. And then they say, please leave. We're going to measure things. And then you come back.

And they say, you got it. But here's the HCI question you
all should be critiquing me for. Wait a second, let's play
the rest of that video.

How does that feel like
to the participant? That seems almost stupid to do. How does that feel like?

And here's how it feels like. And this is the story,
actually, how I met Jun. This is his work, by the way. He did this.

He took it to SIGGRAPH. That's where we met. And people in his demo were
like, this sounds very cool,

but I didn't do it. This is superhumanly fast. I didn't even initiate
the movement mentally,

sending down this downstream
command to say, let's move. It was already happening. He had the whole thing
cranked up to the maximum.

And as soon as the
camera saw a pixel drop, he would fire immediately away. In fact, he had even another
one where there was muscle

sensing on the dropper person. So as soon as that

So when I saw this, a new

which is, wait a second, this
integration is all super fun. And maybe you're as crazy

But I think there's a really,
really, really interesting singularity here.

When you cross from the
wearable to the integration, it's not clear what happens
to the user's sense of agency.

If I can now move your body,
initiate movements for you, that's very, very different. What's interesting is
that a lot of AI folks

are also thinking
about this question because the agency is somewhat
shared once you have systems with initiative to not
just muscle stimulation,

but I want to emphasize that
muscle stimulation cranks it up to a tremendous degree. And so what happened
to our lab is

that this is the thing
we work on the most now-- is the sense of agency question. And it's kind of a
third line of work.

And I just want to point out-- I don't know why
that did it twice. But I just want to point
out what we actually

did to understand if-- can we
speed up your reaction time? Can we give you that benefit?

Maybe you're avoiding danger,
not touching a power line that is high-voltage
or whatever it is. But we want to do that while you
still have some sense of agency

or we're training the
drumming, moving the piano. You want to move. The system wants to move. Intentions are aligned.

But you want to feel like you're
doing something because that actually impacts motivation. So what we did here is
really, really interesting.

We asked the question
of what's happening to people's sense of agency. So I had this crazy
hypothesis when I met Jun that-- and I
was wrong, I must say.
If you do it by yourself-- so y-axis, sense of agency-- x-axis, reaction time.

If you do it very
slowly, but completely by yourself, maximum
sense of agency, you know you're doing it.

Now, let's say I plot here
your fastest reaction time. I do it 100 times. I know exactly how fast
Michael is, for example.

It's here. And you would say, well, if I
assist Michael to go faster, he's immediately going to
report, I didn't do it.

And then I asked my
collaborators, Jun and Shunichi, what if we do it a little
later and a little later

and a little later and a
little later, later, later? Is it completely binary
the sense of agency? And I actually thought it was. I thought it was like this.

The moment you sense something
coming in downstream, upstream that is a little
faster than you,

you should be able
to tell nothing. This is not me. Turns out that's not the case. That's what we found out in this
CHI'19 paper by this experiment

that, obviously, is not
as exciting as a pen drop, but is more control-- that
you can actually do these

measurements very precisely. And then the sense
of agency that you see falls still very sharply.

So you could argue that's
close to that step curve. But what happens is there are
a number of really interesting

points on this curve. So I just want to walk
you through some of them. First and foremost, you can
speed up your reaction time

by a tiny fraction. And you won't even notice. This is crazy. So there are people on
their knees swearing

to Jun during the trials,
I did it, I did it. And Jun is like, uh-huh. He's looking at the log. And it says muscle
stimulation condition.

He's like, yeah, of course,
of course you did it. So that's really remarkable. And this has to do with
the brain's flexibility

to interpret timing. Of course every
circuit in your brain doesn't have a clock
like a computer does. So it needs to have a little
bit of leeway and flexibility.

There's lots of works in
psychology neuroscience backing that up, too. Oh, sorry. But I want to emphasize
that 50/50 trade-off.

And I came up with that semi
out of the blue in that paper. And I didn't know
if I was right here. But what I said
is, what if I want

to get motivated
by doing the task? Maybe I want to pick-- having some speed-up, but
still feeling like half-agency?

And a lot of reviewers
and people are like, half-agency doesn't exist. And I said, but maybe it
motivates people a little bit.

The speed-up is not
as tremendous and-- I could have with this system. But I want to have a
little bit of feeling

that I'm doing it, sort of
like ownership and volition. And I'll show you that
is important later.

So here is the pen
drop with someone that's actually thinking
that they did it. We're delaying the simulation
by 80 milliseconds.

This has to be tuned
per participant. For this person, 80 milliseconds
is a really nice number for them to fully believe it.

And actually later,
with Shunichi again, we found something crazy
remarkable, which is actually,

we can take-- so we trained different
groups of people. One of them trained with very
fast muscle stimulation, how

to perform a reaction
time test, and another one with this delayed
muscle stimulation.

Only the group
that was delayed-- when we took out the
electrodes later, they come back the next day and
they performed the reaction time

test again. They actually had a speed-up. Placebo group-- no clear
speed-up, all over the place.

Training by
yourself-- no placebo. But training by yourself-- no
speed-up, super fast muscle

stimulation. The thing that Jun was doing
with the-- it goes as fast as the camera sees-- no speed-up.

So the motivation-- and
we asked participants, why do you think this helps you? And they're like, well,
I wasn't even sure.

I think it was me. So I was motivated to keep
trying and keep being better. So I'm really excited to
design these kinds of systems.

I'm not really trying to say
that we should have systems that we're dependent on to
learn how to play piano.

We should just learn
how to play piano with the help of these
systems, rip them all out, and now I can perform this task.

And I want to emphasize that 8
milliseconds is really small. But if you play sports or
racket things or whatever,

8 milliseconds is the difference
between you caught the ball and you didn't catch the ball. So in reaction
time, 8 milliseconds is a very substantial
piece of the puzzle.

Now, I want to come back
to this line of work just to emphasize I'm really
getting interested in how

the insights, and I'll get
back to you in a second-- oh, go ahead. Go ahead. So I had a question

Was there a condition where
there was no muscle stimulation, but the target was being
released from further up?

So they actually were still-- None of the studies
were on the pen drop. They were on just a visual

But there was a condition--
we call it sham-- so it's more than placebo-- where we told them there's
muscle stimulation.

We created the fake
muscle stimulation. But there was no movement
of the muscle stimulation. And that doesn't work, either.

That being said,
the interesting part is that sham removes a
little bit of agency. So people are like,
there's something going on.

I'm not completely in
control, although they were. So that's an interesting one. As I was saying, I'm
really excited about this.

And I was surprised, as
well, that you all folks are really excited, too, because
I saw this beautiful poster

yesterday in your-- in
the Gates lobby that says that the Human-Centered
Artificial Intelligence Center.

The right one-- I love
the left one, too. But the right one is
exactly where I'm at.

So how can not only HCI inform
neuroscience and psychology,

but how can we in HCI also
be informed by those fields? And the advancements
in those fields are tremendous for us to unlock
better devices, more design,

more agency, and
so forth, so forth. So I'm a really big
proponent of that part, too. And so I want to emphasize
that this optimization

of the sense of agency is
only during the movement. Notice that the person's
intention is already

aligned with the machine. We tell them, your job
is to catch the pen or to hit the target.

If the intention wasn't
align, that's this paper. Things get more
complicated, of course. I'm not going to talk
too much about that.

But it drops more
dramatically, the agency, if it does the thing
you don't want it to do. Now, the other part
that we're working on

is also we want
to ensure control not just during movement,
but also before or after.

I want to be able to close
these muscle stimulation systems immediately much faster. It's more-- much
more problematic

than how to close Powerpoint. It's like, I don't
want it to override any of my volitional things.

And so we've been
coming up with all kinds of-- in different papers at the
beginning of different tasks, we come up with
different methods.

So over here, you see a person. She always has control
with her non-actuated limb

to turn on, turn off the system. By the way, this
is a paper that's coming out where people
make caramel while they

write an essay. And the muscle stimulation
helps them make the caramel. I'll talk about that
later if you want.

And this one, affordance++ and
an older work of mine where people learn how
to operate tools--

this person picks
up a spray can. And the spray can automatically
starts shaking to tell you, you should shake a spray
can before you use it.

And in this case, if you move
fast outside of the location where the muscle stimulation
starts to come in play,

it automatically dismisses that. So it's a positional control. We've played around with
ideas of tool control.

So I didn't mention, but
in the muscle-plotter one, the moment you lift
the pen, there's a mechanical sensor in the pen.

You lift the pen-- cuts the muscle stimulation off. So you're in control
of that part, too. In an older work of mine,
which, again, I didn't show,

there's gestural control. So this person's arm is
being muscle-controlled. Any movement they do outside of
the area of the muscle control--

for example, catching a
flying pen-- in this case immediately just turns off
the muscle stimulation.

So there's more work
to be done here. But I just want to emphasize
that this is an active area that-- where us
and a few others,

too, are really interested
in trying to understand how to provide more
agency to the systems, but also more control.

Now, another version of this is
you can also go all full crazy and try to talk to the general
public about these things.

And so we made some
artwork to explore the ethical implications of
these extreme forms of control.

This is a sculpture that I made
with Alexandra [INAUDIBLE] years back, and with
Patrick Baudisch, too,

where two people put their arms
in there, in this sculpture. There's nothing else
you can do, really, but put your arms in there.

And what it does is
actually traps you and does muscle
stimulation to your arm. And you-- feeding this power,
this electrical generator power,

to the machine. And this machine actually
lives on in the museum space. This was actually in San
Francisco for a while, by the way.

And it was in Ars Electronica
for a very long time as well. And the machine is just
replenishing its batteries

by sucking people's power. It's a very fun metaphor. And kids and families
love to do this thing.

It's really interesting to
have a discussion with a wider public. It's totally different
from the kind of thing we can do here as academics.

Now, the thing that I
got really interested with this notion
of integration is that perhaps we can do
another thing with this hat

on of post-wearables and
integrating with the body, which is solve some
problems that I think have been plaguing
us for a little bit.

And I don't know
if you've noticed. But I propose a solution. I didn't solve it. But I propose a solution to
the force haptics problem.

So we want to have forces in VR. But the VR headsets are very
untethered, very relaxed, and whatnot.

And with muscle
stimulation, perhaps there's a path to the
future by not having to rely on motors and
batteries and doing the smaller

version of the device. Now, there is another
really, really big problem. And it's great that
the Apple device just

came out because now we
can talk about this problem with even more importance,
which is that we'll also

want to feel tactile sensations
when we touch virtual objects. That person over there--
she's fixing a real engine.

She's in the hololens. And if she touches that
button to hang up the call or touch an interface, she
should feel tactile feedback

because that actually helps us
be more precise and dexterous on the virtual interactions.

The problem is that
this is where industry is selling us, these tactile
gloves that completely

cover your finger pads. And so now you're
having you actually having to choose between virtual
world or shaking someone's hand

or actually fixing
the engine, which is the task at hand in this case. So one thing we've
been exploring

is this almost paradoxical type
of haptics where we want to do-- deliver sensations to the finger
pad or to any target area.

We want to keep that area
free, which is strange because normally,
you need to put the device in the area
you want to stimulate,

like the finger pad. So what you see here
is actually a paper we published last year at CHI
by my student, Yudai Tanaka.

And you can see here someone
climbing in VR, climbing a rope. And they could feel the
texture of the rope.

They can have full dexterity
to grasp and doesn't slip. But they can also
feel that virtual peg

hold as they start bouldering
and grabbing that wall. And the way that that
happens is the muscle

stimulation, which in this case
is called electrical tactile stimulation, is in
the back of the hand,

but in strategic
locations that intercepts the nerves that are going
from your brain to the front.

You have millions of
fingertip receptors over here. They all go through somewhere. And turns out they pass
pretty close to the back side

of the hand. So we put it here. But the sensation happens in
the front, which is really nice.

You can have the hands free. And I'm emphasizing
how important this is because these are the
haptic gloves that they're going

to try to sell you next year. One of them is Meta. It's really beautiful. I've seen it a few times. These ones-- actually
all commercial right now.

This middle part-- you
can buy them all in stock. That one-- so you
can buy it today. And none of this, I think,
is where we should be going.

I think the idea that you
can't shake someone's hand, you can't type on
your keyboard, and you have to choose between
being virtual or being

physical is really,
really dangerous slope for the field of
technical HCI, VR, and so forth.

And So there's been an
important line of research. And Shen-Yuan is really the
person who started it all with

this paper in our lab
in CHI'21, which-- can we do this bizarre idea of
haptics with finger pads free?

So all those devices
leave the finger pads, and sometimes even the feet,
free to feel real sensations,

to walk in the real
world and not fall and so forth and so forth. So we're getting very
close to the end.

I just want to give you
some takeaway messages about this idea of integration. The first one, I think, is
a really interesting way

to think about a
post-wearable world. And from a technical
perspective, it does gives us some
new technical ways

to think about it. If you talk to battery people,
they're very stuck right now. And I think it's interesting
to think maybe this

is an improvement in power
because the type of power efficiency we have to optimize
for is totally different now.

It's also an
improvement in size. So all these devices
that I'm showing here, including some that I
didn't focus too much on,

are really so much smaller than
their mechanical counterparts. Now, the second part
is really this idea

of endowing people
with new abilities-- is something really interesting. And I'm talking
physical abilities here. I think computers do wonders
already cognitively enhancing us

with other abilities. I didn't show you this one. But this is a task
that we actually ask people to do,
as well, which is

to take a photo with a normal
camera of a flying baseball shooting out of the canon.

Of course, none of our
participants could do it. We brought it to SIGGRAPH. It was one person that
said, by accident, I was able to get the photo.

The idea is to get
the ball right there in the middle of the screen. Of course, we can
shoot this whole thing

with the muscle stimulation. Yes, we can
instrument the thing, tossing machine connected
to the finger that

controls the shutter. And now we can take the photo. But remember, we
want to make people feel like they're doing it.

So we're going to delay the
muscle stimulation, again, in this case by 80 milliseconds.

And the person not
only takes the photo, but they actually
feel like they did it, or partially they did it. And they get motivated to learn
the skill better-- so right

in the center of the photo. And remember, I think
it's really interesting that if you take it
out, this was training

this was physical training that
remained in some kind of muscle memory that you have. Now, where I think this is
really interesting-- it moves us

from computers being
super powerful tools for symbolic manipulation and
reasoning, words in our head,

to also being ways to access
tacit knowledge, the ways we do things with our
fingers and body and space.

And so that's where
we're at right now. This paper is coming
out in a few weeks where we showed
that, for example, we

can help people do physical
tasks where they're already good at the tasks individually,
but they're really struggling

to make them in parallel. So this is Aki-- and he's not
a musician, I must warn you-- trying to play a rhythm
that he constructed with a--

piano melody he constructed. He cannot do both
at the same time. But he can choose which
one he focuses on.

One is done by
muscle stimulation. He's playing the
drum pad by himself. And the other one--

or sorry, muscle stimulation
is playing the drum pad. He's playing the piano.

And he's switching now. And so piano muscle
stimulation--

it actually was looking
at what he was doing. It starts looping. He's focusing on the drums.

My postdoc from postdoc-- Jun and I actually worked
on this question a lot. And we started to
ask the question of,

can we even take it
beyond muscle stimulation? So for example, this
is a small exoskeleton that we made that you
wear like a glove.

It's completely passive,
just 3D-printed. And allows you, as a
designer, to access the experience of others,
like what would it

mean to have the size of
a five year old's hand and make a bowl ready
for them to eat?

It's very difficult
for a designer to actually access that. Jun made a study
where designers-- they were designing toys
for kids and just free-form

let them use the exoskeleton
glove or any kind of tools they normally use,
spreadsheets with average ages

and sizes and radius of hands. And they reported to feel
like that embodied design

experience was really,
really important for them. That's what you see over
there when they're testing out

the different grips. And they solve different
problems through this. I'm not saying this is better. I'm saying this is different.

They solve different problems. We also expanded that glove
to the practice and learning

of piano. And we've done this
study with teachers. So you connect physically
to the hand of your teacher. Again, this is not
an electrical device.

This is just a puppeteering
little 3D-printed thing.

And it's really, really fun
to also hear from the piano teachers what they use this
for and how does this impact

their teaching experience. So that was a really
fun study to do. And more recently,
with the help of Terra, who works on protactile
language, the language

of deafblind individuals, we're
actually using this, as well, together with them to see if
we can learn their language.

Can we speed up the way
we learn their language, understand the microcues they
use when they move their hands?

So this is Jun
actually learning how to move his hands through a
protactile individual who's

showing him how he
moves his hands. Now, I know I focused
a lot, and this is pretty much my
last slide-- focused

a lot on nerve stimulation. But I think this idea of
integration goes beyond--

just want to emphasize one
work by Jasmine, my student who is integrating
living organisms--

this is a little living
organism that lives inside of your smartwatch. And you have to take
care of it every day because if you don't, your
smartwatch physically dies.

And this idea is
really interesting because it makes people
consider the interactions and the relationships
they have with the device.

Participants in this study who
live with this watch for a month were really scared of
letting it die, trashing it,

and started to think of
the environmental impact of electronics and all that. So it's a really interesting, if
you want, umbrella or analogy.

You can use this idea of
integration on your own work, too. That's what I'm thinking. Now, I just want
to-- final slide--

thank the sponsors, thank,

[LAUGHTER] You wanted this one? Considering-- assuming there's

in learning-- so the
play the piano example-- is there a way to just

Yes, that's what Siya
is up to, this person. Siya is doing that now because--

I agree with you. And I've talked to Jakob, a

And he agrees with
the two of us, too, which is if we
just make people move, then they don't have this

that the muscle stimulation

waits for you and either
corrects you or helps you or just pushes you in the

to be more effective. She has some initial plots.

And what it seems to be is that
people are better at chunking when you learn by using little
different chunks of the music

piece or whatever it is--
with the active part, you're better at chunking. And that's great for

learning tremendously. So that's a great question. We're thinking the
same direction, too. I think you were next.
Do you want a-- Yeah. There you go.

Yeah, huge. It's huge. Did I have a slide about that? I used to have a slide about
that because that happens.

That happens. Is it here? It is. So there's a number
of limitations.

And you see number 3
is electrode placement. So electrode placement
is a really big problem

with muscle stimulation. 1 millimeter can change. But not only that,
really, the rotation

of your body, the skin,
and the inner muscles don't rotate in the same way. You can all try that by--

touch your skin and just
see how your body rotates in a different way inside. So that's by design
from the body.

And so we tried to work
on all these in parallel. The calibration stuff is--
we're not even there yet.

But we just recently
started working a little bit on the placement. One way you could try to
circumvent the placement

that I've seen some
people in HCI doing is imagining that you
not only have electrodes that you have to
manually place, but you

have a sleeve with 100,000
electrodes, all very small. And could you let
the system figure

out which ones are necessary? The system randomly
tries to sample them all and observes the resulting
movements and then says,

oh, it's this, this. It's like what we do when
we manually place it. One irony of all this is
that we don't know why--

I've tried to have those
systems do it for you and see if they're faster
than a human at calibrating. And it seems like me and
all my grad students,

including [AUDIO OUT]
when she was there doing some muscle stimulus. We're all better
than that system. So there's some equation
that we have here

that maybe tacit knowledge
base that we know how to calibrate the system better. Another way to avoid
the electrode placement,

but you're going
to be scared by it, is to directly go to the brain.

And so Yudai and I have
been working on that. So what you see here,
actually, is a person

receiving haptic feedback by
means of muscle stimulation, except the stimulation is
